speechtext: Can the hon. gentleman give any information concerning the repairs to the Minto. I understand that when she arrived at Charlottetown she was immediately put into dock and had to be repaired before attempting her season's work.

The hon. gentleman was incorrectly informed. The Minto, on her voyage out from England, encountered one of the most severe storms her captain said he had ever experienced in the Atlantic. Some parts of her deck fittings were smashed by the ice, and the iron work twisted, but this had nothing to do with the hull or any material part of the vessel, and there never was any complaint against the builder. But certain changes, not very material, and almost always incidental to a new boat, had to be made. After her first winter's experience in the ice, the Minto had to go into dock to be re-riveted, but the same thing occurred when the Stanley was built, after she had a season's experience in the ice. There was, however, a larger number of loose rivets in the Minto than in the Stanley, and I communicated direct to Gourley Bros., asking them whether, considering the number of rivets that had to be re-riveted, they should not bear their share of the expense. They replied, giving in detail the great pains taken in their shipyard to have everything done in first-class order, and asked me, as they could not
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: How much was the cost ?
$4,900 for re-riveting and putting it up.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: How much was the cost at Charlottetown, before the Minto was regularly in commission ?
I do not recollect, but I stated the amount in debate last year.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: The Miuto, I presume, was built after tender, and a regular contract drawn up ?
Yes.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Did the hon. gentleman ask, as a matter of favour or fair-play or as a matter of law, that the contractor should contribute towards the expense of re-riveting.

I have no claim as a matter of law at all. I simply submitted the facts to them as first-class shipbuilders. I stated that after one year's experience in the ice, 1,300 rivets had to be re-riveted, and asked them could they afford this. I suggested that they should pay one-half. As a matter of law, she was certified in first-class condition, and the captain of the Minto intimates that he never had as good a boat before, and is thoroughly satisfied with her in every respect. We have no fault to find, except that, as the resuit of the year's work, more rivets require re-riveting than should be the ease.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: How does the cost of maintenance compare with that of the Stanley ?
A little more. The Minto is 25 feet longer and proportionately broader and has a few more men, but the cost is very little more.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Who is the commander ?
Captain Finlayson, promoted from the Stanley, and the first officer of the Stanley is the captain.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: What proportion of expenditure is attributable to repairs and what to maintenance ?
Nothing special. Every year we come down with the supplementary estimates whenever the repairs are more than the ordinary.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Why is this increase from year to year in the maintenance and repairs to government steamers ? In 1900 the amount was $145,000, and in 1901, $160,000.

I can hold out no hope of the expenditure being any less. It will rather be likely to be increased, because there is an additional steamer this winter. We have two steamers on the route trying to keep winter communication between Prince Edward Island and the mainland.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: And not succeeding ?

Both were frozen in fourteen days, but are running again. The Stanley got out of the ice yesterday, and the Minto three or four days ago. $160,000 is the ordinary sum voted, and when any special repairs are required we ask for a supplementary estimate.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: What was the amount expended last year, on which this estimate was based ?
There was $160,000 spent, and $20,000 supplementary voted, or $180,000, including repairs.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Why not make it $180,000 this year ?
Because the practice has been to vote the repairs in the supplementary estimates. I think the better plan would be just to bring down the exact sum, hut I simply follow the practice.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: I think that is a new practice. The system on which the estimates used to be based a few years ago, took into consideration the total expenditure. Regardless of whether a boat was obtained by original or supplementary estimate. Bringing the estimates down in this way, a steady increase might escape the attention of the Committee. Evidently, $180,000 is the amount the hon. minister will require, for that was the amount last year and the year before; and, as I understand him, he does not hold out any hope that he will require any less this year.
Certainly not.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Referring to the question put by my hon. friend (Mr. Monk), can the hon. minister tell us how much of that is apportioned to maintenance and how much to repairs ?

Last year there was a supplementary vote for the Min to of $12,869, and alterations to the Aberdeen, $7,000. I shall propose this year's supplementary estimates for alterations and repairs to the Druid, the Aberdeen and some other steamers. I shall certainly require the whole $180,000. There will be the expense of running the additional steamer this winter.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: But, what I wished to ascertain is, how much of the expenditure is for maintenance and how much for repairs ?

Substantially the whole of this is for maintenance-small ordinary repairs are included. Where there is a special expenditure amounting to five, six or seven thousand dollars, I intend to ask the House for a special vote, naming the amount and the vessel to be repaired.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: The hon. minister does not understand me, 1 take it that his officers have given him in detail the estimated expenditure for the maintenance of each ship, and also for the repairs of each ship. It seems to me a pity to have the Marine Deportment, which has its special officers, nautical men, men who are acquainted with the repairing and the handling of ships, give up the charge of these vessels, and allow other departments to run vessels on their own account. construction of both these ships in Canada ; and as my hon. friend says, even if it does cost a few thousand more, it will be in the general interest of the country that the money should be spent here, when that can he done, so that we may help along this great national industry.

In that connection, has the hon. gentleman given attention to the efforts being made at Halifax to establish an iron ship building industry, and has he considered how far the government would be able to go on encouraging that enterprise, even if they have to pay a little more, by having the next large ship required for the use of the government on that coast built in Canada ?

I have given that matter a good deal of consideration and, as much as two months ago, I had the whole matter reported upon by the officers of my department. I appreciate fully the importance of this great industry of building iron and steel ships in this Dominion. So far as the government is concerned, it will be my earnest desire to do what I can to further the initiation of that great industry. 1 made a report to my colleagues on the subject and suggested the desirability, when tenders are being called for, of calling for tenders in the Dominion of Canada for the construction of these ships. 1 had obtained beforehand an estimate of the increase in the cost of building in Canada, and submitted that to my colleagues, and although the report has not yet been finally adopted, they viewed the suggestion very favourably, and I think the conclusion will be to call for tenders in the Dominion of Canada for these ships. When I say ' these ships,' I include the Newfield, which is to take her place on the Nova Scotia shore, and also the Druid, which has been reported as worn out and useless, and as too dangerous to undertake another season's navigation, and for which a new ship will have to be substituted. It is my intention to call for tenders for the
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: 1 am certain the feeling in Canada would justify the additional expense that would be incurred in patronizing what would certainly be a new industry on the coast, or anything like an attempt to build a seagoing ship, iron or steel, and to assist in that respect. It would be a mere bagatelle so far as the government is concerned. Those enterprising are risking their own capital in an effort to make a test, at any rate, whether the country can sustain such an enterprise ; and I feel sure, without having directly communicated with any one, that the spirit of the country is such to-day the people would be delighted, in every quarter of Canada, not only to see this enterprise successfully started, but to give credit to the government for any share they had in assisting in such a way to develop that industry.

I notice on page P-144 of the Auditor General's Report, a reference to a steam barge called the Shamrock, purchased at a price of $21,500. May I ask the minister where that craft is, from whom she was purchased, and what use she was put to ?

She was purchased for the Montreal buoy service, as I explained last year. Previously to that the Montreal buoy service had been let by contract, and had been, carried on by contract. But it did not give satisfaction. The boards of trade and the shipping industries of Montreal insisted that there should be better buoy service, and the government had to take it over and carry it on themselves. A ship was bought from Mr. Kane, I think the name was-the facts are not as fresh in my mind as they were last year when I gave the House all the information about it.

I must say I do not find the explanation of the minister satisfactory. I think when we vote such a large amount as $160,000 we are entitled to know in a precise manner what is going for repairs and what for maintenance. When I asked the hon. gentleman that, he said : Oh, that is the usual annual vote. As a matter of fact the vote reached the figure of $160,000 in 1900 ; before that it was $145,000. Then the hon. gentleman says : I intend to ask for $20,000 for extraordinary repairs. Then he says further on :	It
ought to be $180,000 anyway. For his own part he was of the opinion that it was better to make it $180,000 right away. And during all this time the hon. gentleman is not able to tell us, as surely he ought to know, what amount is going for maintenance and purely annual repairs, and what amount is destined for extraordinary repairs, and what amount is destined for the purchase of new ships. I think this is a most unsatisfactory manner of getting through an item of that magnitude. When we have an amount for maintenance and repairs, why have we not for the purchase and building of new ships? why have we not the amounts separated ? It would be much clearer, and we would lose much less time.

I am sorry my hon. friend does not think the explanation satisfactory, but I made it perfectly plain. The vote for $160,000 for maintenance and repairs refers chiefly to the maintenance of ships, but it also embraces some ordinary small repairs, if there are any. I told the hon. gentleman last year, when I asked for a large amount required for repairs in a special vote in the supplementaries. that 1 proposed to ask for it tin's year again. They are not hidden or covered up. This amount is not for the purchase of the ship.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

I have not brought it down yet.
I told the hon. gentleman what it was last year-$12,869 for the Minto and $7,000 for the Aberdeen. This will be brought down with the supplementary estimates. This item of $160,000 is the ordinary item for the maintenance of the ships.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: If the hon. gentleman would allow me, why does he then contend that the vote should be $180,000 every year for just these ordinary expenses of maintenance and repairs, and why is it that the hon. gentleman cannot tell us what is the specific amount required ?

The $160,000 I now ask for is practically and substantially for the maintenance of the ships. If there are any other sums required for repairs, I propose to bring them down as a supplementary estimate.
I have said that I would have to ask for $30,000 this year in addition to this $160,000 for repairs. This $160,000 is for maintenance. Last year the vote was taken in the same way, and I had to bring down an estimate for repairs, and I gave the hon. gentleman the items. speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

I wish to ask the Minister of Marine and Fisheries (Sir Louis Davies) why it is that when the Stanley was at Summerside on the 22nd of December no facilities were provided by which she could carry the mails, passengers and freight to Cape Tormentine. The Stanley remained there for ten days without doing any service and she was withdrawn at the very moment when she would be of some utility in keeping up communication. I wish to ask the minister (Sir Louis Davies), why that occurred and why ar-

rangemehts were not made for the maintenance of that communication as we expected it would be.

It is true that the Stanley was detailed to make the experiment of crossing from Summerside to Cape Tormen-tine in the month of December last. She would have gone earlier to her berth at Summerside but for the reason I have explained to the hon. gentleman from 'Gasp6, her boilers had to be repaired after the summer's work on the fishery service. The very day that the work was finished she proceeded to Pictou, coaled there and went straight to Summerside to make the experiment of keeping open the winter passage between that and Cape Tor-mentine. I had informed the board of trade of Summerside some time previously that there were no terminal facilities at Cape Tormentine, and that I thought it was inadvisable to make the experiment until these facilities were provided. They, however, pressed upon me very strongly that the attempt should be made and I submitted the matter to Captain Finiayson, of the Minto, who has had some twenty-two years experience, and to Captain Brown, of the Stanley, and they advised that it was possible that if the board ice formed for half a mile outside of Tormentine pier they might be able to land on the board ice, and they advised that the experiment might be made. On their report I sent the vessel there. The board ice did not form; they had to land near the pier. The pier was in such bad condition that the ballast had fallen out and prevented the bow of the vessel getting near it. There was no way therefore to land freight if they had carried it. and until my friend the Minister of Public Works (Hon. Mr. Tarte) is able to get that pier repaired it would be impossible for the Stanley to utilize it as a terminus. I am in hopes that this season the minister (Hon.- Mr. Tarte) will be able to repair the pier. The Stanley made the experiment of crossing and recrossing every day and successfully for a time, but the smallpox broke out in the district near to Cape Tormentine. Passengers would not travel through the region where the smallpox was supposed to be, and a very large number of people in Prince Edward Island were averse to the service being maintained through an infected district of that kind. The mails were not, and ought not be sent, that way, and after the Stanley had made a number of trips without carrying freight, passengers, or mails, there was no use continuing her on the route any longer and she was ordered to go to Pictou. At Pictou there was an enormous congestion of freight which one steamer could not move, and the idea of sending the Stanley to Pictou was to give daily communication with Georgetown, one boat running each way. We were very successful in moving the freight, and until the other day when
we got into this terrible storm there never was a time when the winter communication was maintained so admirably as it has been this winter. I am in hopes that next winter the terminal facilities at Tormentine will be -so improved that possibly the Stanley will be able to utilize it, and continue the experiment between Summerside and Tormentine.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: I am at a loss to find that there was any special grant available up to July 1, 1900, for the purchase of the Shamrock. I find that there is no mention made of it in ' Hansard.'
I find on inquiry from my advisers that I was correct in the statement that there was a grant.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Then it is unfortunate for the hon. gentleman (Sir Louis Davies) that the discussion on it should be entirely eliminated from ' Hansard.'
Has the hon. gentleman (Mr. Bennett) got the supplementary estimates ?
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: I have ' Hansard ' in which the discussion would have appeared.
Has the hon. gentleman got the supplementary estimates ?
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: I have not under my hand a copy of the supplementary estimates; but there was no discussion on the question in the House at all. It follows that nothing more has been heard of it until we find this reference in the Auditor General's Report of this year ; and of course a member of the House could not know of anything that transpired between the Auditor General and the minister until it did appear in the Auditor General's Report. The Auditor General took exception, it would seem, to the payment of this amount, whether because the boat had not been purchased in open market or by contract or for some other reason ; and I think it is fair to ask for an explanation why, in the face of that letter of November 7, the amount was paid over, assuming that it has been paid.
The amount was paid over, as I think my hon. friend will see, long before that objection was made.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Why was the objection made ?
The hon. gentleman knows why the Auditor General takes exception. It is a matter of faith and duty with him.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: He was all right when we were in power.
The ex-Minister of Railways said he was not.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: But you said he was.

The Auditor General's objection, as I understand it, is that he did not think the Deputy Minister of Marine had sufficient knowledge to give the certificate required by the 33rd section of the Audit Act. We differed with him, that is all.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Was the boat purchased in an open sale ?
Yes. The purchase is a most excellent one,- and I do not think any one would .question it.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: The Auditor General did.
No, he merely asked if we had a certificate from a technical officer, as required by the 33rd section of the Act.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext:
I can only express my surprise that the hon. minister would send the Stanley to the route between Cape Tormentine and Summerside without seeing that she had proper facilities for doing the work. The most expert captain on Prince Edward Island in connection with ice breaking, reporting to the minister on November 1, made this statement-the hon. gentleman referred to it, but his explanation was not strictly in accord with the report made by the captain :
The only thing, in our opinion, that can be done to test the route is this: after the steamer Northumberland stops running, place the Stanley at Summerside andhave her all ready and let her remain there until the board ice in the vicinity of Cape Tormentine breakwater is sufficiently strong: then a landing can be made on the ice. This has been done at Souris and Georgetown on several occasions.
That is exactly what I said.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext:
That condition of things arose. The Stanley was held at Summer-side for ten days to make daily trips between that port and Cape Tormentine. There were no mails, no passengers, and no facilities at the Tormentine side to advance the communication. About the 1st of Janu-ry, when the Stanley was withdrawn, the very conditions laid down in the captain's report existed : the ice had formed, and there was no difficulty in landing mails and passengers. The hon. gentleman refers to the smallpox scare. We know how important it is to the people of Prince Edward Island to have this communication. There is to-day in Ottawa a case of smallpox ; but must this city on that account be cut off Mr. COCHRANE.
from communication with the outside world ? Some smallpox may have existed in the county of Westmoreland in the vicinity of Cape Tormentine ; but the nearest case was six miles away from the Cape, and there was no danger. Mails and passengers could have been landed at Summerside without difficulty. But through some oversight the boat was taken away-it cannot have been on account of the smallpox scare. I noticed in a paper a day or two ago that when the minister was at Charlottetown, the board of trade of that city waited upon him with a memorial, asking him to leave the steamers Stanley and Minto on the route between Georgetown and Plctou in order to relieve the great congestion of freight at those points. What was the fact ? The two boats were stuck in the ice hard and fast for a week or ten days, and could not relieve the congestion of freight. If one of the boats had been left on the route between Georgetown and Pictou, and the other placed between Summerside and Cape Tourmentine and $1,000 had been spent on improvements at Cape Tormentine, there would not have been any congestion. When the Stanley was at Summerside she had on board a full cargo of coal, and still she was able to come to that port and discharge part of the coal, and make daily trips between there and Cape Tormentine. I think there has been some misunderstanding or bungling, or we would have a service between Summerside and Tormentine to-day.

There has been no misunderstanding and no bungling. I promised that an experiment would be made ; but I warned the board of trade when I made the promise that inasmuch that there were no terminal facilities at Tormentine for the landing of the Stanley, the experiment would be made under disadvantageous circumstances, and I doubted that it could be made successfully. But they pressed for it, and the experiment was made. The steamer was released for a variety of reasons which I have stated to the committee. The smallpox may have been one of them ; the absence of terminal facilities at Tormentine was another. While I do not want personally to call in question the opinions of those who believe that a route can be established there, I may state that when I crossed the other day in an open boat from Traverse to Tormentine, I found the pier at Tormentine completely covered with ice to a height of nearly thirty feet ; so that even if the Stanley were running there, it would have been absolutely impossible for her to have gone near that pier. I do not want to throw cold water on the experiment. I promised that it would be made ; and the boat was not taken from Summerside until after the captain had reported to me that he had spent two or three houis in getting out, and

that if the frost had become harder he would never have got out. I telegraphed back to him to use the best judgment he could, and to continue the test until he concluded that it was not possible to make the trip. I did not order him away without using the best judgment I could, and I think the hon. gentleman agrees with me.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext:
The hon. gentleman is asking us to vote .$160,000 of the people's money for the maintenance of five or six government steamers, and I want to inquire if it is his intention to spend that money, or at least as much of it as goes for supplies, by calling for tenders ; or is he going to continue the bad practice, which he says he followed when he came into power, of dealing it out to his political friends. As to the practice, we contradict his statement, because we say that the late government purchased practically all their supplies by tender. Has the hon. gentleman expended this money in the interests of the country as he promised us when given the vote ? Turn to the Auditor General's Report of last year and you will see that the bad practice, to which I drew attention time and time again, and which the hon. minister promised he would remedy, has continued and even become intensified. I find on page 8 that twenty-four bushels of onions were purchased for the steamer Aberdeen at a $1.50 per bushel, and each of the steamers uses the same quantity. I would ask any farmer if $1.50 per bushel for onions is a price this government ought to pay. But that is not all. $1.50 per bushel is paid for turnips and the same price for carrots, and 31 cents per pound for beans. Would anybody else pay these prices?
Then, take this new steamer Minto, my hon. friend had a political heeler in Montreal to whom he wanted to give $1,000 or more. This was B. .1. Coghlin, whom everybody knows as Barney Coghlin. The hon. gentleman sent to Mr. Coghlin's retail hardware store and bought some $1,265 of supplies from him for that steamer.
The Minto never was in Montreal.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Look at page P-19 of the Auditor General's Report.
The Minto never was in the province of Quebec.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext:
I did not say she was there, tout Mr. Coghlin was, and you wanted to benefit Mr. Coghlin so as to help you in the elections, so you gave him $1,265. You sent your agents to Mr. Coghlin, who does not deal in crockery, and without calling for any tenders at all. you purchased from him $361 worth of crockery, * for which there is not one voucher. There 9
is an invoice for four dozen table knives, $26.06. Any gentleman in the House, who is a hardware merchant, may turn up page P-19 of the Auditor General's Report and see the prices there marked for supplies purchased from Mr. Coghlin, amounting altogether to $1,265. There are four teapots of three gills each, $40.87, or $10 apiece for a little teapot. And so the list goes on, every dollar spent without any advertisement for tenders, and every dollar spent on political friends of Ijon. gentlemen opposite. Travel through that book from one end to the other and you cannot find a dollar paid to a Tory storekeeper, is the hon. minister going to continue that way of doing business, in spending the $160,000 he is asking us to vote, or will he spend it in a business fashion ? Why not ask for tenders and give fair open competition, and not give political heelers two or three prices for each article required.

I shall not quarrel with my hon. friend for calling respectable gentlemen political heelers, but I cannot hold out the hope to him that I will depart from the old system, in practice many years, of seeing that our friends get the patronage and not our opponents. The only question is, are we paying fair and reasonable prices or not V I can tell my hon. friend that the greatest possible care is taken against overcharging. Every account is severely and closely scrutinized before it comes to the department, and the accountants and officers in charge are specially* responsible for the examination of the accounts. If they find any overcharge they must at once send back the account. The hon. gentleman singled out one case.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: I could single out a thousand.
But the hon. gentleman did not, and I shall deal with the one he singled out. He referred to Mr. Coghlin, of Montreal, as a political heeler. Well. Mr. Coghlin is a most respectable merchant.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Yes, I know him well.

He is a very large merchant and he happened to be in Glasgow when' the Minto was being built. Mr. McElhinney was in charge of its building. Mr. McElhinney was not an appointee of mine, and I suppose the hon. gentleman would call him a Tory heeler. He was an officer of the department, in the discharge of the duty of supervising the building of the Minto, and Mr. Coghlin obtained from Mr. McElhinney an order for these supplies. Would the hon. gentleman like me to dismiss that Tory officer for having given that order ? The hon. gentleman may rest perfectly assured



that the patronage of the department will go in the future, as it has in the past, to the friends of the government, provided always the latter give good articles at reasonable prices.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: I would refer my hon. friend to page P-12 of the Auditor General's Report, and he will find there that Louis Marois, of Quebec, supplied carrots at ifl.50 per bushel. I do not object to the government giving its political supporters the preference, but I do think that it should do business on business principles, and not spend hundreds of thousands of dollars on supplies without inviting any competition. Some time when we are going into Supply, I will divide the House on that question. Can my hon. friend justify paying $1.50 per bushel for carrots and three and a half cents per pound for beans, and $1.50 per bushel for onions ?

The agent of the government at Quebec is Mr. Gregory, an old and experienced gentleman, who has held that position for many years. He has been cautioned to examine every purchase himself and certify to the charges being reasonable and fair, according to the prices ruling for the goods in the province of Quebec. If the hon. gentleman will move for the accounts, they will be produced before the Public Accounts Committee, certified to by Mr. Gregory. I have no other means of stating that the prices are fair than the certificate of my agent at Quebec.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: It was quite refreshing to hear from the government the absolute repudiation of the main plank in their antielection speeches. There is to be no calling for tenders at all, but they are going to buy fairly from their own men. They are afraid to allow Conservatives to tender, because the Conservatives might tender lower than the friends of the government. It is quite pleasant to hear the frank avowal that contract by tender is a thing of the past.
Is it usual for any of the agents to make objections to prices as excessive ? Has the hon. minister any cases of that kind ?
Numbers of them.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Will the hon. minister say what takes place then ?

If the sellers attempt to make an overcharge, payment is refused.
Ocean and River Service-Examination of
masters and mates	 $5,000
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext:
I notice that the expenditure under this head last year was $3,700. Is it necessary to ask for $5,000 this year ?
Sir LOUIS DAVIES

In a general way, the work is carried on the same year after year, but the amount expended varies somewhat.
Ocean and River Service-Rewards for
saving life, including life-saving stations $9,000
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: There are a great many complaints about the loss of life in a wreck at Long Point, on Lake Erie, in August last. I would like to ask if the authorities at Washington have complained to this government or to the Department of Marine and Fisheries of that loss of life ?
As far as I know, there has been no complaint, direct or Indirect, from the Washington authorities.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Is there any particular object in the increase of $1,000 in this vote ? I see by the Auditor General's Report the expenditure last year was a little over $7,000, and the estimate this year is $9,000.
The increase is to provide a uew boat at Point Pelee. The old boat was reported to be out of date.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext:
What is done with the old boat ?
The	MINISTER	OF	MARINE	AND
FISHERIES. Practically it was of no use. A few dollars may be got for it.

Is it the intention to improve the life-saving stations on Lake Erie?
The	MINISTER	OF	MARINE	AND
FISHERIES. It is.

Is it the intention to procure a life boat for Port Credit, on Lake Ontario, in accordance with the petition presented a few days ago ?
The	MINISTER	OF	MARINE	AND
FISHERIES. I do not recollect the presentation of that petition. If it was presented it may be awaiting attention. It will receive my best consideration.

The hon. minister's answer to me is hardly consistent with this vote. Last year the estimate was $8,000. and this year it is $9,000. The hon. gentleman does not expect to make much improvement for $1,000, I suppose ?
There will be a new boat.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Is that all ?

I do not know if any other special improvements are required except to keep closer inspection of them. Instructions have gone out to keep up inspection of boathouses and boats, and to make the crews perform their drill more regularly

than some of them have in the past. Much will be gained, if we make the crews more efficient than they were.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: The hon. minister will observe that Port Stanley and Port Rowan are the only two life-saving stations on that portion of Lake Erie. The dangerous point is at Long Point, where the storms take place. I am aware that the American representative at that place has complained very strongly to the authorities at Washington concerning the sacrifice of life owing, as he believes, to the imperfect life-saving stations on the Canadian side of Lake Erie.

I can only say that nothing will give me greater satisfaction than to give the closest and most courteous attention to any suggestion that the hon. gentleman (Mr. Ingram) may make as 'to improvements of the life-saving stations on Lake Erie. If he will make these suggestions to me as head of the department privately, or make them publicly in the House, I can promise him they will receive full consideration.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: This $1,000 increase is to purchase a new boat. How much does a life-boat cost ?
The deputy minister tells me that the boat will cost about $600.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: And the balance, I suppose, is for some equipment ?

Yes.
Ocean and River Service-Investigation
into wrecks	 $1,000
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Does the hon. minister proceed to investigate on the mere report of a wreck, or does he require official recommendation ?
I require application to be made by some reputable person.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Then the investigation is held as a matter of course ?

Yes. if a shipowner, or other reputable person, asks for it.
Ocean and River Service-Registration of
shipping	   $500
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext:
I have a suggestion to make. The registration of shipping is taken care of by officers of the Customs Department, and, I supopse, the expense is counted as part of the expenses of that department. Occasionally a man in the customs is sent from his own place to another for the purpose of examining the books, to see that the registration is uniform. As a matter of fact, I may say, the books are not uniformly 9i
kept. Books are provided, as I understand, at the expense of the Department of Marine and Fisheries
No.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Then, at the expense of the Customs Department. These books are uniform so far as the blanks are concerned, but, in filling in the blanks, there are great differences. Some customs officers are careful and some are careless ; and, in the latter case, beyond the name of the boat, her tonnage and a few essential items, the matter is passed over. My suggestion is that there should be an officer to be called inspector of registrations. No additional expense would be incurred, it seems to me ; for some gentleman now in the Customs Department, who does not have too much to do and who is familiar with the work, would be assigned to this duty. The effect of his work would be to secure uniformity as well as greater care in the registration of vessels. Although the expense would be greater in the Department of Marine and Fisheries, it would be less in the Customs Department, and there would be less money spent than there is to-day. Of course the vote asked here, $500, is not a very large amount; and, looking at the Auditor General's Report, I see that only about $200 spent last year is properly chargeable to this item of the estimates. But I think that better service would be rendered if it was put under the charge of some man in the employ of the Marine and Fisheries Department, and if it were provided that all the registration, both inland and ocean, were systematized and better kept.

I shall have to consult my colleague in whose department this legislation is carried on. All we do is to provide books for the registration. As to appointing an inspector, my hon. friend's experience does not accord with mine. If you detail a man to do additional work of that kind you have to assign additional pay. However, we will consider my hon. friend's suggestion.
Tidal service, including salary of assistant
clerk beyond $100, notwithstanding anything in the Civil Service Act	 $7,500
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext:
In regard to this, I am sorry that although some progress is being made, the government cannot see their way to expedite this very important work. There seems to me no reason for nibbling at it, as the government are doing, when the coast line of this country is considered. The amount expended is only about $4,000, because the rest of this vote is in salaries, and you have a high class man whose salary is near the appropriation outside the amount spent. This work was long ago completed with the United States, on both the Pacific and At-

lantie coasts, and completed In India, and in the British Isles. With iron and steel ships, and with the growth of these steamers in size and all that sort of thing, it is a most necessary work. Take, for instance, the question of the insurance rates. While it is true that the ordinary seaman and the ordinary mariner of the smaller class of vessels have very little concern about the result of these surveys of the tides, the officers in command of all the large oceangoing steamers are required to understand them, and it takes a technical training to understand them. But it seems to me a disgraceful thing that we should proceed so slowly. It is a smaller vote now than I was able to get at the initiation of the work. I know there is very little general interest taken in it-we have discussed that already. Some rough and ready seamen think that because they have got along so well without these tables, which many of them cannot understand, it is merely a scientific fad. But one need only to refer to the Admiralty in England, to the leading men in connection with shipping there, and also to the official hydrographic staff of the United States, and the work in India, to understand that these surveys are of tremendous importance. Now the government is committed to the principle, they are carrying it on, the $4,000 is a mere bagatelle. I am glad to see that assistance is being given, but I would be far more pleased if, in addition to that, the hon. gentleman were to take a substantial increase, which this official and his assistants could spend to advantage. He has no ships, he has no facilities such as are required. I do not think the hon. gentleman will find that the United States, or India, when they were dealing with this work, made such slow progress, or satisfied themselves with so small an appropriation. I would be glad if the hon. gentleman could expedite that work in accordance with its importance.
I would be glad if my hon. friend could defer this discussion until the supplementary estimates. I am considering the matter, and perhaps I may be able to make a statement on the supplemen-taries.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext:
I agree with what has been stated by the hon. member for Pictou (Sir Charles Hibbert Tupper). It would seem that this service is somewhat at a standstill, and that some new departure is proposed to be made. Now I see there is a considerable increase, apparently, in the work to be done in the hon. gentleman's department. In 1900 I find that $4,000 was voted for that service, in 1901 that was increased to $7,200. The hon. gentleman explains a part of it there, as it appears in the estimates, by saying that an extra clerk had $400 of it. Then again there is still another addition of $300 in 1902. Will the Sir CHARLES HIBBERT TUPPER.
hon. gentleman say what new circumstances have grown up in the office requiring this increase ? It seems he requires to employ an extra clerk. The hon. gentleman thought that some of those clerks were only employed for a very short portion of the year, yet the vote was taken.

I do not quite gather that my hon. friend objects to the increase. I went into it in great detail last year when the same question arose, and I pointed out to my hon. friend the data. We have tidal stations at different places on the Bay of Fundy and along the coast of the Gulf of St. Lawrence, for gauging the rise and fall of the tides, and the data ascertained at these different tidal stations are taken and tabulated at the head office here by Mr. Dawson and his assistants. We were some years behind in this work, and Mr. Dawson intimated to me two or three years ago that unless he could get these returns properly tabulated and printed in a book, it was no use collecting them at all. So some additional clerks were given him for the purpose of tabulating these statistics gathered at the different stations, and when they are tabulated they are sent home to the Hydrographic Office in Great Britain, and printed in a book. I think last year I brought down a copy of the book, a very large book, showing the rise and fall of the tides at these different stations. From this data so gathered, tide tables are prepared by Mr. Dawson, showing the tide at different harbours in different ports, so as to be of use to the mariners, showing them when the tide rises, when it falls, when it is half tide, when full tide, with the depth of the tide, and so on. It was necessary to employ these additional clerks in order to utilize the information which was being gathered, and which, until it was tabulated, was useless.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: I would like to ask another question which has been considerably discussed in the newspapers in reference to a proposition to adopt some system of damming to raise the water in Lake Erie for the purpose of counteracting, to some extent, the withdrawal of water from the upper lakes by the Chicago drainage canal. I would like to ask the hon. gentleman if any proposition of that nature has been made to the government of Canada by the United States authorities.

I will ascertain whether it was ever made in the department in my absence. No such proposition ever came before me personally, and I am almost certain that had it come to the department, it would have come before me. It never came to the department.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext:
Perhaps the hon. gentleman would ask the Minister of Public

Works (Hon. Mr. Tarte). I think he had an interview with some of the papers throughout the country.

No, I do not think that I ever received any such proposition. [DOT] There may be some letters; I have a vague remembrance, that some letters were written to us on that question, hut not in the way of any proposition.
May I ask the hon. gentleman in reference to this vote for the hydrographic survey if this work has been carried on in the Georgian Bay.

No; we will come later to that.
Winter mail service	 $8,500
speakername: The MINISTER OP MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Could the hon. gentleman tell me in what way this $8,500 is to be applied ?
It will be applied as far as it can be for the boat service which is now going on.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Was this service organized so that it would be in readiness ?
Yes.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext:
It seems to me very strange that on February 2, the Minto crossed over to the island with the last mails before being locked up in the ice, and that ten or twelve days elapsed before we had a crossing with the mails at the Capes. If this service was organized, why was it not given. During the late election when I was campaigning in that portion of the district, my opponent was using the mail service to his advantage, saying that it would be duly equipped and organized and ready to perform the service. We find that from February 2, to February 12, there were no mails to or from Prince Edward Island, and the Board of Trade of Summer side, had to ask the post office inspector at Charlottetown, to ascertain if anything could be done to forward their mails by ice boats. They finally came to their senses and allowed this to go on. I cannot understand why this was not done at first. We did not have any mails from the province of Prince Edward Island, until the 13th February, and if this service was organized it is very strange that the mails were not brought over. We asked about this the other day in the House, and the hon. Postmaster General got up and in a very light manner said : You will get information about your mails when the hon. Minister of Marine returns. We know from the papers that the hon. Minister of Marine and Fisheries had a very thrilling time getting across. That may interest the hon. minister and his friends as an adventure, but it has nothing to do
with the commercial facilities of Prince Edward Island.

The explanation is a very simple one, but rather a painful one for me. Nobody understands more clearly than I do, why you did not have mails between Prince Edward Island and the mainland for 12 days. It was for the simple reason that a violent storm was raging during which no boat could cross. I was imprisoned myself. No one could desire to leave the island more earnestly than I did, but I could not get away. I went once or twice to the cape to see if I could get across, but the captain would not start, and the judgment of the captain's was right. They could not start. The boats started out at the earliest possible moment they could cross. The opposition boats crossed one day from New Brunswick to Prince Edward Island. They went during a north-west wind. The next day our boats crossed from the Island.

Hon. WILLIAM ROSS (Victoria, N.S.) In connection with this item I would like to make a few observations on the salaries paid to lighthouse keepers in general. I do not think that any system has been adopted in Canada to classify the lighthouse keepers as regards the salaries paid them. In the United States-I am now speaking of Maine and Massachusetts-the lighthouses are classified and the salaries regulated accordingly. With ns, the keeper of a revolving light on an island several miles from the shore gets $400 a year. It is impossible for

liim to keep that light going all the time without assistance, and that assistance must be paid. In the United States these assistants get $600. In our wealthy Dominion the keeper gets $400, and perhaps the next keeper to him. who has a fixed light, gets the same salary. I do not think that there has ever been any regular system or rule applied to the salaries of lighthouse keepers by any government since confederation. If, for instance, a lighthouse is erected at a particular place, and the representative of the county has influence enough with the government, the salary may be fixed at $500, while another place where the representative may not be so influential, the salary may be less. Let this House fancy the condition of a man on an island, keeping a light going all winter, with the assistance of one man, and very often obliged to find his own fuel, and receiving only $400. All I can say is that that is the only resignation of a lighthouse keeper that has been presented to the department within five years because of insufficient salary. At the present moment there are two vacancies in the maritime provinces, and there are no less than a dozen applicants for each light. A good deal of what my hon. friend says may be true. There may be a case here and there where the salary of a lighthouse keeper is hardly commensurate with the labour he has to perform ; but it must be remembered that these people are free of all taxes, house rent, and expense for fuel and light, and that they get $400 cash in addition. hap hazard way. I beg to assure him that that is not the case. The same officer who has advised the Minister of Marine for many years past with regard to the salaries to be attached to these offices, is in the department to-day. You cannot fix the same salary for Prince Edward Island, Nova Scotia and Cape Breton, that we have to pay on the Great Lakes or in British Columbia. What would be considered an adequate salary in the maritime provinces would be considered utterly inadequate in British Columbia and in the far-off parts of the province of Ontario. I saw an intimation some time ago, given in an interview with one of the ministers of this government, that it was contemplated to light the St. Lawrence very much better in the coming year between Montreal and Quebec. I understand that one reason given for the very heavy marine insurance is because the channel is not properly lighted.

I make no admission of the kind. I do not admit at all that the St. Lawrence route is not properly lighted. I do not mean to say that we cannot spend more money on that route, but I have crossed the Atlantic with five or six of the best sea captains who have ever sailed out of Montreal and have put this question to each one. I told each one that I was putting the question in my official capacity as

Minister of Marine, and intended to use bis answer, and on tbe last occasion I bad tbe good fortune of baying two of my colleagues present. Tbe question X put was tbis : Do you know of any aid to navigation between Montreal and Belle Isle wbicb is now wanting, wbicb you would recommend being put there, or any aid to navigation now there wbicb you think ought to be improved. In each case tbe answer was no. The last gentleman to whom I put tbe question, tbe captain of the Parisian, qualified bis answer by saying : You know, I think tbis light at Point D'Amour in tbe Straits of Belle Isle, has bad something coming over it tbe last few months, and you should send an inspector to see what is the matter. I replied that with a naked eye I could not see anything wrong, but would send an inspector down tbe first thing in the spring. I do not mean to say that no improvement can be made, and before tbe supplementaries are through, we may have a special vote on this subject. We spent $40,000 to $45,000 in building a permanent pier at the Traverse and erecting a light there last year, which has been of the greatest possible benefit to the shipping interest. Instead of having a lightship there, we have this permanent light. When the cold came on and the ice formed, the lightship had to be* taken away, or it would be carried away by the ice altogether. With a permanent pier and permanent light there we are enabled to prolong the period of navigation for some time with safety. It is now under consideration-and I may say that personally I favour it-to construct a permanent pier at the other end of the Traverse, about two miles and a half further down. It will cost $75,000 or $80,000. If I can get the approval of my colleagues, and if the Finance Minister is able to grant it, I may ask the approval of the House, at a future time for the vote. There may be other large votes for the improvement of the navigation of the St. Lawrence, besides this. Anything that is submitted to me and which I can be satisfied is a real improvement, will be willingly accepted by me. For. I recognize the vast importance of that St. Lawrence river trade, and the absolute necessity of avoiding cheese-paring in our expenditure upon it to put it in the most effective condition. I do not hesitate to say that I am desirous of going as far as anybody else, short of extravagance or useless expenditure, in recommending the use of every dollar that is necessary to place the navigation of that route in the very best condition. If there are aids to navigation still needed, I wish to put them there ; if any that are there are defective, I wish to improve them. I am willing to listen to suggestions from any side of the House. The subject is under consideration, and I may have some additional votes in the supplementary estimates.

speechtext: Before this item is adopted, I would like to ask the minister whether he has given further consideration to the memorial from the board of trade of the city of Halifax as regards the establishment of a lightship off the harbour of Halifax, During the last session of the last parliament I brought the matter to the attention of the hon. gentleman, and quoted a memorial which, I think, had been forwarded to him previously, and also a letter from Captain Pye, of Halifax, with regard to the difficulty of hearing the bombs fired from Sambro Island during foggy weather. The hon. gentleman at that time said the matter had been investigated by certain officers of his department, and in respect to some matters mentioned in the memorial, they did not agree with the views expressed by the board of trade ; and that with respect to the best place for the location of a lightship, if one were necessary, the views of the board did not agree with the views of the chief engineer of his department. I understood from what the hon. gentleman said on that occasion that he proposed to give liis further attention to the matter; and I also understood him that he would submit to the board of trade of the city of Halifax the report of his officials in order that they might have an opportunity of considering it and of making such reply as they thought desirable.

I may say to my hon. friend that I have given a great deal of consideration to that matter, in conjunction with the officers of my department, both here and in Halifax, and I have taken advantage of opportunities from time to time of consulting with the captains who enter the port of Halifax and leave it, but I have not yet officially made up my mind upon it. The chief engineer of the department is rather averse to the idea of placing a lightship there, because he does not think it is even
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: necessary. He looks upon tlie Halifax harbour as one of the finest in the world, with the lights which are there now, and he is backed up by the opinion of Admiral Erskine, which he quotes from time to time, who thinks that there is no difficulty for the largest ships in the world sailing right into Halifax harbour without danger. But there are others who hold a contrary opinion, and X am inclined to think that I did carry out my promise to which he calls attention, and send to the Halifax Board of Trade the opinion of the officers upon their memorial. I may be wrong in that, but my recollection is that I did send it. I will refresh my memory upon it. The matter is not finally closed ; it is still under consideration by Ool. Anderson and myself, and I do not want to shut the door one way or the other. I had a consultation with my hon. colleague the Minister of Finance (Hon. Mr. Fielding) upon it. It was brought to my attention some time ago, and I took advantage of my presence in Halifax to consult with the officers there. I went over the charts very carefully, and took the opinions of the officers. I met the inspector of lighthouses, Mr. Hutchins, and Capt. Campbell, lately in command of the Newfield and others. But, I have not come to a conclusion which would justify me in making any recommendation to my colleagues, nor do I mean to say that the door is closed one way or the other. I will again take the matter up before the supplementary estimates are brought down.

The hon. member for Quebec West (Mr. Dobell), who has great practical experience in matters of this kind, and who has had some practical experience in respect to the necessity of a lightship at the entrance of Halifax, when he spoke of this subject, during the past session, said :

He went on to express some doubt as to whether there was holding ground at that point, as to which I think, after what we have heard upon that matter during the past two or three years, there is really not much doubt. I understand that so far as the question of holding ground is concerned there is not really any difference of opinion among the hon. gentleman's officers. speechtext:
The reason that I speak is that the hon. minister, in referring to the list, read one or two items for maintenance at a lighthouse at Middle Ground. I assume that no maintenance will be required, unless it is intended to build a lighthouse there. This lighthouse, if built, will be to replace one at Point Pelee, which was burnt a year or so ago. A discussion has arisen in regard to where that lighthouse should be built. I understand that the department has decided that it would be rebuilt at Middle Ground, and I am informed that that is not the best place to have the lighthouse. This is certainly the most important lighthouse of any between Duluth, or Chicago and Kingston. More vessels are interested in this point than any other on the upper lakes. They say that Middle Ground is not the best place at which to build a lighthouse, and I understand that strong representations have been made to the hon. minister in that regard. It is perhaps important that a lighthouse should be put at Middle Ground, but if so there should be two lighthouses at that place. It is called Middle Ground because it is land

lying between Pelee Island and Point Pelee itself. If one lighthouse is built there, the other one ought to be built at Point Pelee, on what is called South-east Shoal, which is just near there. That is the one that will best serve the marine interests. I am told that there was a deputation of mariners down, and probably they had an interview with the minister upon that point. If so, it might be very satisfactory, and in the public interest, if the minister could say that he has been convinced that Middle Ground is not the best place to adopt, but that if he intends to build one at Middle Ground, he will have one built at South-east Shoal on Point Pelee itself. This is a very important matter, and I know that a great many people are interested in it and anxious to know at the earliest moment what the department intends to do. I am satisfied that 'the best interests of navigation will not be served by a lighthouse at Middle Ground, which will not answer the purpose at all. It will be good enough as far as it goes, but it is not the best place. It is not as good a place as to build it exactly on the spot where the one was destroyed. But better still would it be to put it on South-east Shoal, and better still would it be if there were two lighthouses, one on Middle Ground and one on South-east Shoal.
I am not asking for any vote now for the construction of a lighthouse on Middle Ground or Point Pelee.
speakername: The MINISTER OP MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: We cannot see what you are asking for.

It is therefore, hardly fair to ask me to give explanations in as much detail as I would give if I were asking for a vote. Last season when I asked for a vote, I brought down a chart, and the matter was argued and debated. The different locations where it was proposed that this lighthouse should be built were considered, and Middle Ground was preferred. I said in the House that the department had received petitions from a large majority of the captains of the craft in reference to the location, stating their opinion that the proper place to build the lighthouse was in the Middle Ground. I speak under correction, but I think that with two exceptions, they were unanimous in believing that Point Pelee was not the proper place, but that Middle Ground was the proper place. In addition to the opinion of the mariners, the captains of vessels, there was the opinion of the chief engineer, which was thoroughly concurrent, and there was no opinion of any weight or moment advocating the construction of this lighthouse at Point Pelee. There were very serious objections against building it there.
speakername: The MINISTER OP MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: What about South-east Shoal ?

There were serious objections to that too. The Middle Ground was the one which was at that time determined upon, and a vote was granted by parliament on the understanding that that was the location where the lighthouse was to be built. The lighthouse has been built and will be ready for the spring. It would have been done last fall but for the storms in October. I beg to assure my hon. friend (Mr. Britton) that if he is under the impression that the majority of the carriers favour the construction of a light on Point Pelee, he is entirely mistaken. I will bring down the petition, which will show that the vast majority are in favour of constructing the lighthouse on the Middle Ground.

speechtext: In a place like this, even with the best lightship, she is liable to move, and then the danger is greater than if there never was a ship there at all. But, this proposed lightship will be fitted out in a way which I think would avoid any reasonable possibility of that. Before I proposed the vote last year, Col. Anderson went down to New York, and the engineers there gave him every information as to the improvements made on these lightships, and which are now used very largely along the American coast; and he gives me to understand that with these improvements, there will be no, danger at all of the lightship moving.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: The hon. gentleman's ground for asking this vote is rather slender, especially as this is the second year it has been asked. He tells us that it is asked on a mere surmise.

I beg pardon; I did not say that. The bon. member for Pictou was asking about putting up a permanent structure, instead of a lightship, and I said that I had received a suggestion of that kind from an engineer of St. John, and that before I made any of the proposed expenditure, I would make inquiries and see if there was anything in that suggestion.

The hon. gentleman is wrong. We know that several vessels were ' lost there, one particularly three years ago; and the investigation with respect to the loss of that vessel, which was pretty thorough, satisfied my mind at all events that if there had been a lightship on the Lurcher shoal, the vessel might not have been lost.

speechtext: I am not objecting to the appointment of any necessary official. Why should we maintain even a small staff of officials for the purpose of maintaining provincial revenues. The minister I am sure will agree with me, that this is a useless service for the Dominion to maintain and that it should be ended as speedily as possible. Is it the intention of the government to maintain this service and to multiply the officers as the necessity arises ?

It is not the intention of the department, while I preside over it at least, to multiply unnecessary officials. I appeal to the experience and intelligence of my hon. friend (Mr. Clancy)-and I have never appealed to them in vain-for he knows that the Privy Council decision gave rise to certain anomalies which we did not anticipate and cannot overcome. The exclusive power to make regulations in connection with the fisheries is vested in the Dominion government, but the provinces of Ontario and Quebec having been declared by the Privy Council to be the owners of the beds of rivers and lakes, they were held a fortiori to be the owners of the fish in these rivers and lakes, and it was held that the provinces had the exclusive right to grant fishery leases of areas in these lakes. Therefore the revenues which we formerly derived from the issue of licenses are now

handed over to the provinces of Ontario and Quebec.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: We all know that.

I am explaining the anomaly. We must make the regulations, and they grant the licenses. With the constitutional duty cast upon us of making the regulations, are we not to see that the regulations are carried out ? WTould the hon. gentleman (Mr. Clancy) suggest that I should withdraw the Petrel from Lakes Erie and Huron? I do not think any one would suggest that.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Is not the Minister (Hon. Sir Louis Davies) wrong in regard to that decision of the Privy Council, when he says the result of it was that the authority of the Dominion government was gone with regard to the issuing of licenses ?
Leases ?
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: The hon. gentleman said licenses. We had a system of licenses in the province of Ontario which brought incidentally into the exchequer a very large sum of money. As I understand it, the decision of the Privy Council did not interfere with that system or the right to charge for these licenses because they were not for revenue but for the purpose of restriction, and preventing overfishing.

I would not be dogmatic on that question, because there is room for difference of opinion. I have consulted with the Minister of Justice, and the Deputy Minister of Justice and also with Mr. Chris-tojther Robinson as to what that judgment means, and the conclusion I arrived at was that while we may have the power to levy a tax on all fishing we choose, outside of that we have no power to issue a license and charge for it in the provinces of Ontario and Quebec.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: I take it, there would be nothing wrong in our passing a regulation that no one should fish without paying, say one dollar a year. speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Quite so, hut the curious thing seems to be that the federal authority has absolutely withdrawn from Ontario in so far as that license system is concerned.
Yes.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: That license system never was founded upon a revenue basis, but upon the necessity of protecting the fisheries so as to preserve them. That was the attitude always taken in this House, and when a comparison was made of the large amount taken from Ontario as compared with the other provinces, the explanation of the policy of the government was that this was a mere incident, the system not being to obtain revenue from the fishermen of Ontario but to preserve to these fishermen the fisheries, and with that end in view a fee was charged for tugs and for nets and so on. That being so, there is not a line in the judgment which says that system is wrong and that the provinces alone should charge a license. The provinces of course exercise proprietary right, but according to the statement of the minister (Hon. Sir Louis Davies) the Ontario government are carrying out that license system and obtaining the incidental revenue from it.

As I understand the hon. gentleman, the Ontario government own the fish in the rivers and lakes of the province.
I would like to know if the Ontario government endorse the regulations of the Dominion government, and are willing to carry them out.

They undertook to pass regulations supplementary to ours, contending that as the proprietor of the fisheries, they had a right to make supplementary regulations. That is our contention. We have taken the opinion of the Justice Department on it once or twice, and we have no reasonable doubt as to the righteousness and legality of the ground we stand upon in that regard. I want an inspector to report to me whether the regulations are being carried out. Yes.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

Yes, full power.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: The passage of the decision which I have reference to is not long, and I would like to bring it to the attention of the minister, because it underlay what I suggested-that these regulations under which the license fee was charged, were passed as regulations, and not for the purpose of retaining any money. Passing to the question of fishery and fishery rights :

Their lordships are of opinion that the 91st section of the British North America Act did not convey to the Dominion of Canada any proprietary rights in relation to fisheries. Their lordships have already noticed the distinction which must be borne in mind between rights of property and legislative jurisdiction. It was the latter cnly which was conferred under the heading, ' Sea Coast and Inland Fisheries,' in s. 91. Whatever proprietary rights in relation to fisheries were previously vested in private individuals or in the provinces respectively, remains untouched by that enactment. Whatever rights might previously have been lawfully made by the provinces in virtue of their proprietary rights could lawfully be made after that enactment came into force. At the same time, it must be remembered that the power to legislate in relation to fisheries does necessarily, to a certain extent, enable the legislature so empowered to affect proprietary rights. An enactment, for example, prescribing the time of the year during which fishing is to be allowed, or the instruments which may be employed for the purpose (which it was admitted the Dominion legislature was empowered to pass) might very seriously touch the exercise of proprietary rights, and the extent, character and scope of such legislation is left entirely to the Dominion legislature. The suggestion that the power might he abused so as to amount to a practical confiscation of property, does not warrant the imposition by the courts of any limit upon the absolute power of legislation conferred. The supreme legislative power in relation to any subject-matter is always capable of abuse, but it is not to be assumed that it will be improperly used.
That was brought out much more strongly in the argument on the interruption of the counsel, when Lord Herschell made an observation directly on the illustration which counsel was making on the basis of that license svstem.
As a matter of policy, we have not attempted to issue general licenses.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: As I understand the hon. gentleman, he has no advice from the Department of Justice that it would not be possible for this government to issue licenses. It seems to me the language of the Judicial Committee would indicate that you might issue licenses. ' Fishing regulations and restriction are within the province of the Dominion, inasmuch as the exclusive legislative authority of the parliament of Canada extends to sea coasts and Atlantic fisheries.' In the well-known case of the city of Toronto vs. Virgo, it was held that the by-law in question was ultra vires, because it destroyed the trade or right which it purported to regulate. The Judicial Committee of the Privy Council held that regulation could only be consistent with the continued existence of that which is to be regulated. Here you have the power to regulate, why not exercise it by means of licenses as well as anything else ?

We might do that and possibly charge for the licenses too, but I would

draw a distinction between a general license to fish and a license to fish in a particular locality. The latter would be a matter affecting the proprietary right. For Instance, if we should divide off from the shore a certain location, A to Z, and give a license to fish in that location, that would amount to a lease, and should come from the province alone. A general license we might issue, saying that nobody shall fish in the province unless he has a Dominion license, but as a matter of policy we have not adopted that system.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: My hon. friend has said that the Dominion government has given up all claims for the revenue from licenses in the province of Ontario. Why have they not done so in the province of British Columbia ?

There is a broad distinction between the two. The reason on which the judgment of the Privy Council was based is that the proprietary rights in the fisheries belong to the provinces of Ontario and Quebec, inasmuch as the beds of the rivers and lakes are the property of the provinces.
In the maritime provinces, the question whether the bed of the sea, from low water mark, to the three-mile limit, belongs to the province as a proprietary right, or whether the Dominion has proprietary jurisdiction over it, is a question not absolutely determined. I have frequently expressed my opinion that the Dominion has the right over the sea coast fisheries and that the provinces of Ontario and Quebec have the right only to the inland fisheries, because they own the beds of the lakes and rivers.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: A large number of the licenses collected by the Dominion in British Columbia are licenses to fish in the rivers.

Not many, but there are some, and an adjustment is being made in the accounts between the province and the Dominion in that regard. I had a lengthy interview with the premier of British Columbia. on the matter. I admit that if I were to give exclusive leases of any part of a river and charge for them, the fees would belong to the province ; but if I give a general license to fish and make a regulation that nobody shall fish without that license, that is within my power.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: My hon. friend said some time ago that he would have to make a larger expenditure in British Columbia than he has done in the past. To strengthen his hands with his colleagues, and especially with the hon. the Finance Minister (Hon. Mr. Fielding), of whom he seems to be afraid
Oh, no, you will find the Finance Minister very generous.
