speechtext: Let me draw attention to some figures I have just taken out of the Auditor General's Report. In Ontario the revenue was $794, and the Dominion government expended there $3,704. In Quebec the revenue collected amounted to $2,563, and the expenditure was $5,549, or the expenditure doubled the revenue. In Nova Scotia the revenue was $5,494, and the expenditure $27,461, or there was five times greater expenditure in Nova Scotia than revenue collected. In New Brunswick the revenue was $12,015 and the expenditure $21,459-or the expenditure nearly doubled the revenue. But in British Columbia where the revenue was $53,195, the expenditure was only $13,662, or the expenditure in that province was only one-fourth of what the government received. The revenue collected from British Columbia was four times more than that collected from New Brunswick, and yet the expenditure in New Brunswick was one and three-quarter times that expended in British Columbia. And while the revenue from British Columbia was more than ten times that of Nova Scotia, Nova Scotia had twice as much expended in that province as British Columbia. Those figures show that British Columbia once more came out at the small end of the horn, and I trust that the hon. minister will take those figures into consideration and establish more fish hatcheries in British Columbia and appoint more overseers to look after the lakes and the rivers.
I appreciate a great deal of what my hon. friend (Hon. Mr. Prior) has said. He will find that the expenditure for the current year is much larger.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: It is the same old thing. Always promising.
No, the hon. gentleman will find that the expenditure is larger, and it will necessarily and properly continue to increase.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext:
I notice a great increase in the expenditure for the protection of fisheries in Prince Edward Island within the last few years. In 1895-6 the expenditure was $3,555, and in 1899, it was $7,264, an increase of one hundred per cent in four years. Will the hon. minister tell us what changes have taken place in Prince Edward Island to warrant such an increase ? I know of none. The fisheries are no better protected than they were. We have had a number of by-elections, it is true and several defeated candidates-and that is the only way I can account for it. Last October, when I was going about soliciting the votes of the people, I went down to Richmond Bay where the oyster beds are, and I found there a regular swarm of men paid by the government, the object being, no doubt, to

elect the government candidate. The fishermen were being watched as closely as if they were preparing to steal something that belonged to the government. The object was to secure support for the government, but it did not have that effect. The time when the fishing is going on is not the time to protect the fisheries. The time when watchfulness should be used is during the spawning season. But, when the men are fishing, do not put on a force of camp followers to watch them at their work every day. As I have said, the hon. minister is losing prestige among the fishermen by using the men in this way. Merely that he may hand over'the loaves and fishes of government patronage to the men who were wandering in the wilderness for eighteen years hungering for the flesh pots of office. This may be a growing time, but the day may come when the government will require every dollar they are now throwing away in this reckless manner. I had the honour to be inspector of fisheries for Prince Edward Island for a number of years. In 1895 I found the amount placed at my disposal quite sufficient to protect the fisheries. Since then, as I say, the expenditure has increased a hundred per cent and it has been increased for a corrupt purpose, to influence the electors.

As the hon. gentleman (Mr. Hackett) knows, and as every hon. gentleman knows, it is not a very popular thing to enforce fishery or any other regulations, and, in the attempt to enforce properly the regulations of the department and preserve the great fishing industries of the people, an officer or a minister will not gain, but will lose popularity. The hon. gentleman is right in saying that I have not gained in popularity in my native province, but have lost. But I should be recreant to my duty if I allowed men to break the regulations I have sworn to carry out. The increase of expenditure has been made in an honest effort to protect the lobster and other fisheries. I know it is very unpopular, but I intend' to do it, as I have done it in the past.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: There is one point respecting this fishery expenditure to which I wish to call attention. In the report of the Auditor General with respect to overseers or wardens appear sums such as these: Salary 9 months, $45 ; travel, $294.05; salary 9 months, $75, travel $204.49 ; salary 9 months, $75, travel $782.56. It seems to me that the salary is very small in proportion to the travel. There seems to be very little bread, to a monstrous deal of sack in this case. When a man travels to the extent of $782, it seems to me he should be paid more than $75 for it.

It is very difficult to explain Mr. HACKETT.
to the hon. gentleman this apparent an-nomaly, but it is all right. A man is paid a certain sum as guardian or overseer of a certain district. If he sits at home and does nothing, he might as well not have been appointed. If his district is a large one he should travel long distances. He must keep a record of all the travelling he does, where to, and the number of miles. He must make a return, and this is checked by the officers of the department. A man cannot be expected, for $50 a year, to take his horse and carriage out or to travel by rail or boat at his own expense. Therefore, the department allows so much a mile for travelling fees. The law allows payment only for mileage actually travelled bona fide in the discharge of the duties of the office. The question is whether we have a good check upon these returns, and the officers in the department think we have.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: The $50 or $75 is in the nature of a retainer then, and the other represents not actual expenses but a mileage allowance really part of the salary ?
Yes.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Has the minister had any complaints from his inspectors that the Ontario officials have failed to carry out their duties in enforcing the regulations ? If not, the only reason for the expenditure for inspectors is the burning zeal of the hon. minister to carry out a duty that is already well discharged by those who have the greatest interest in discharging it faithfully. If he is prepared to say that cases have come to his notice, that might be a reason, and if he is prepared to say further that he has taken means to remedy the evil complained of, that would be a reason ; but, if the hon. gentleman is not prepared to make a statement of that kind, then, I submit, they are absolutely of no use, and there is no reason for retaining the inspectors to do work that is being well done simply because it is in the interest of the province to do so.

I can only tell my hon. friend that he must have failed to follow the statement that I made before, that is, the absolute necessity of retaining some officials in the great province of Ontario to keep the department informed as how their regulations are observed. The hon. gentleman sees it is not a matter of whether the officials of the Ontario government carry out their duties to their superiors that I am concerned with ; they may collect their fees or they may not, they may issue licenses properly or they may not, that is not the point that I am concerned with. The point I am concerned with is this : Are the regulations that this department makes from time to time the proper regulations and,

secondly, if tliey are, how are they observed by the fishermen ? Now, I must have somebody to inform me from time to time whether those regulations which are made by the department as to times, and seasons, and methods of fishing, are proper regulations or whether they should be amended. It is not the duty of the Ontario officials to do that, and if I have not got an official there to do it, it will not be done at all. These officials make reports from week to week, not how the Ontario officials discharge their duties, but how the Ontario fishermen observe our regulations, and whether those regulations are right or whether they ought to be amended. From time to time we receive our information from our inspectors, which we transmit to the Ontario officials for their information, and, therefore, we keep in touch one with the other. It is not our fault if these apparent anomalies exist between the powers of the Ontario government and the powers of the Dominion government ; the Privy Council is responsible for that, for its declaration of what we formerly supposed was not the law. So, I say, it would not be good policy on the part of this government to withdraw altogether from the great province of Ontario the presence of two or three officials, who travel about from week to week and fortnight to fortnight to keep the department here informed as to whether our regulations are good and proper, and whether they are being properly observed. Now, if I found out from the reports of my inspectors that these regulations were not being observed, it would become my duty to appoint officers to enforce them. It is part of the duty of these inspectors to" enforce them if they come face to face with any breach of them. On view they could convict and punish any offender against the regulations, and it is their duty to do so : and if they fail to do so we must appoint others to do it, in case it is reported to us that breaches become numerous. So far we have no material grounds of complaint. Of course complaints are always coming in, being investigated, and disposed of ; and, speaking generally, we are getting along fairly well. There must be some friction existing between the Ontario government and the Dominion government, each not being quite sure where the line of their duty ends and where the duty of the other begins. However, this will adjust itself, it is adjusting itself now from season to season. I think my hon. friend would be well advised not to ask us to withdraw the only officials we have there, but to ask us to keep down the expenditure to the lowest possible notch.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext:
My hon. friend has still failed to make out his case, as it seems to me. The hon. gentleman bases his case principally upon the fact that he is anxious to know how these regulations act upon the
fisheries of the respective provinces. Now, if it is conceded that the hon. gentleman has a right to make the regulations regarding provincial fisheries, it is a fair presumption that he makes them in the best interests of those fisheries, and in the best interests of those who are solely concerned. If that be true, is it not also a fair presumption that if they are not working well, representation will be made to the hon. gentleman's department by the provincial officers ?
No, I do not think so.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: It is the most natural thing that if these fishery regulations are harsh and are not working well, the parties concerned will inform the hon. gentleman. He does not require a set of inspectors to inform him if these fishery regulations are not working well and require amendments. I can understand that if a set of regulations made, not in the interest of the Dominion, but in the interest of the provinces, were found to work contrary to the anticipation of those who made the regulations, representation would be made to the department at once. The true test is the fishery officials in the province, and not the inspectors over the inspectors, as the hon. gentleman has them. The provincial officials are better judges, as they report to their principals whether those regulations are working well or not. The province will always communicate to the Dominion in matters of that kind, especially since the hon. gentleman says that they always keep in touch in regard to these matters.
What objection would there be to imposing those duties upon provincial inspectors ?

We have no power to do so. I would rather be relieved of the necessity of appointing an army of these provincial officials.

speechtext: What is the policy of the government with regard to these fish hatcheries now, since the fisheries are given over to the provinces ?

We have made no change, we have determined to carry on the fish hatcheries. There is a slight increase here in the amount asked for maintenance of fish hatcheries in Canada. There will be three new hatcheries, one in Margaree, county of Inverness, Cape Breton, one at Gaspg, and one in Sicamous, Granite Creek, B.C., and a small one at the mouth of the Skeena river, in British Columbia also. The hatchery which as been started at Gaspe is a combined lobster and salmon

liatchery. Lobster fisheries are entirely under the control of the Dominion, being a deep-sea fish ; and salmon may be con-siderd, while it is in the river, to be a provincial fish, but in the sea it is a Dominion fish. However, the policy in the Dominion has not been altered in respect of fish hatcheries by reason of the Privy Council decision. We have gone on, at all events, and parliament seems very generally to have approved of the fishery expenditure. I think it is money well spent. A large number of those engaged in the lobster fisheries believe that a large number of the small lobsters, innumerable almost, three, four and five inches in size are the result of the Pictou lobster hatcheries. Whether it is so or not, I cannot positively assert, but their presence in very large numbers within a reasonable area from the place where the spawn are deposited by the fish hatchery officer leads to the reasonable conclusion that they are the product of the fish hatcheiy. Taking it all in all, I think the money is well spent, and unless there is a very strong opinion expressed in parliament against the continuance of the expenditure, I should be disposed to advise its continuance.

At the conclusion of the fishing season, in sending in the annual report of the Frog Pond feezer for 1900, Mr. Larkin, the president, further writes :
Permit me now, at the close of our season's business, to enumerate or place before you some of the benefits derived by our people from having a constant supply of fresh bait. Last year (1899) our cove, with the same number of boats and men engaged in hand and ' set ' lining, took some 95,000 pounds codfish, hake and haddock. During this season the weather was fine ; we had very few mackerel along our shores, and so the men devoted the greater part of their time to the pursuit of codfish, hake and haddock. A great deal of time was lost trying to procure a supply of bait. Ballentyne's Cove, N.-S.-Commenced operations on April 25, 1899, and fourteen tons herring were frozen and stored. The fresh bait season was exceptionally good, better than for many years past. Mackered struck in early and provided an excellent supply of bait. In consequence, the fishermen did not require the frozen supply. Owing to neglect to ice the storage room frequently enough, two tons of herrings were spoiled. The charge was ultimately converted to other uses. The presence of the freezer was, however, a guarantee that bait would at all times be available. This freezer will be operated by the fishermen during the coming season.
Frog Pond, P.E.I.-Commenced operations in April, 1900, and has proved a great boon to this fishing settlement. The president of this association, writing about the middle of the past fishing season, states : ' I am buying most or nearly all of the codfish caught in this vicinity, and am keeping a record of the kind of bait they were caught with. Our fish books show over one-half our total catch has been caught with frozen bait. Furthermore, were it not for the constant supply of bait insured to the fishermen by the bait freezer, not one-half as many people would engage in the busines for the simple reason that it would not pay the men to engage in this business -without the certainty of a constant and sure supply of bait. I feel quite certain that we are on the eve of a new era in the codfishing business around our shores Sir LOUIS DAVIES.
who in the first season had not any great faith in frozen bait, kept some nets out; sometimes they got a baiting, sometimes only part of a baiting. Those people tested the matter thoroughly, and so satisfied did they become with the frozen bait that they took their nets ashore. We have some very practical and observant fishermen in our cove, and they declare that so long as a supply of frozen bait is to be had they will not set any nets during codfishing season, the supply of bait from nets, they say, is no better when had. Again, there is no certainty of obtaining bait every fine day.
I might say just here that we had twelve shares of stock unsold when we met on the 22nd. During the meeting we offered them for sale ; within two minutes they were all taken-taken by fishermen who had a share each before. This will give you some idea of the faith and estimation which our fishermen have of frozen bait, and the benefits derivable therefrom.
You will observe on looking over the sheets where a record of bait taken and issued appears that our fishermen knocked off fishing early this year. The reason for this is that this has been an unusually stormy season. In all my experience I have never known anything like it. With weather such as we had last year (1899) we would have certainly doubled our catch. Another cause for more fish, codfish. &c., not being taken was that in the month of July and the early part of August mackerel struck in -quite plentiful ; our men paid considerable attention to that branch of fishing at the expense of the other.

I may say for myself that I am more than ever convinced of the benefits derivable from having a bait freezer in our midst.
Alberton, P.E.I.-Commenced operations in May, 1900 ; ten tons of fish were frozen. The directors did not provide sufficient ice to carry the charge until fall, when the Caraquette fleet from New Brunswick make Tignish and Alberton their headquarters^ In consequence, no decisive results were obtained. Used locally, the bait gave satisfaction.
Port Hood Island, C.B.-This freezer was finished in October, 1900, and a supply of ice being available, a test charge of one and one-half tons of squid were frozen and used in December. The secretary of this association writs :
' We had our freezer completed about November 20, 1900. As we had some ice left over from last year, we transferred it to the new ice-house, and commenced freezing squid. We froze about 3,000 pounds on trays and in crates and kept them for future use ; the result was that after the middle of December there was no bait on the fishing ground, and the fishermen were glad to use bait from the freezer.
' Some boats caught over $100 worth of fish, using frozen bait, which they would not have caught if they had not bait from the freezer. One fisherman states that he earned his three shares in the freezer on New Year's Day, over and above his neighbours who baited on salt squid, fishing on the same ground and with more trawls than he had ; all were expert fishermen.
'The fishermen here were always doubtful about the value of frozen bait; now they are very favourably inclined towards our freezer, and expect great benefit from it next season. I also have frozen a quantity of haddock and codfish, and expect to supply fresh fish to Port Hood and vicinity during March and April.'
Neil's Harbour, Victoria County, C.B.-A freezer was built at this point by. private enterprise from the department's plans, and was not under the supervision of the department's inspectors. Mr. M. G. McLeod, who was principally interested, writes : ' Our Neil's Harbour cold storage did not prove a success owing to the ignorance and carelessness of our men. A lot of squid was packed in it, but in such large quantities that they got red before they froze. Had the squid been properly frozen they would have been worth at least 1,500 quintals of codfish to us.
' When we will get the Neil's Harbour storage to work well, it is sure to pay, and possibly better than any other cold storage in the province of Nova Scotia. It was not the fault of the cold storage that the squid did not keep well. The storage, I believe, is all right, and with some experience, will be worth thousands a year to our fishermen and ourselves. If the squid had kept in our storage last fall we would have more codfish stored away for winter than we could handle for drying next spring. Next year I hope we will be able to give a good report.'
In the report of the Fisheries Intelligence Bureau, under the direction of Commander O. G. V. Spain, for 1900, Messrs. A. N. Whitman & Sons, of Canso, N.S., remark : ' The laudable efforts of the Dominion government to establish bait freezers along the coasts are meeting with gratifying success, and it looks as though in a few years every fishing port of any importance would be supplied with one. Properly managed, they must materially add to the catch of fish.'

Some discussion on this subject took place last year. The ground of the objection taken then was that this measure interfered with private enterprise which would supply the want now supplied by the government. That is a very rosy report ; and if everything in it is true, there would seem to be no necessity for the government bearing any share of the cost of this undertaking. Another feature that was discussed-I am not attempting to criticise, but merely to state the objection raised in the former debate-was that this bait was sold to American as well as Canadian fishermen. I would like to ask the hon. gentleman if that is true, and if so, do the government feel bound to take the place of private enterprise in order to furnish bait to American fishermen ?
The MINISTER OF MARINE ANI) FISHERIES. The hon. gentleman will remember my stating last year that the greatest possible care would be taken not to interfere with commercial enterprise. In Nova Scotia, New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island there are many places where the fishermen congregate in fishing villages, and where there is no great inducement to prompt commercial men to undertake the establishment of freezers. Most of these will be built for the benefit of the fishermen themselves. Few, if any, will enter into Sir LOUIS DAVIES.
competition with the bait freezers established by such men as the Whitman Bros., for commercial purposes ; and I may say that the enterprise which the government have entered into has the warmest encouragement and support from such men as these. It cannot do other than increase largely the supply of fresh fish. I know of nothing which this government have put their hands to on a small scale calculated to produce better results than the assistance we have given to the bait freezers. Everywhere it is appreciated, and everywhere it is doing good. Of course, there are cases in which the licensed American fishermen may purchase bait, where the bait freezers choose voluntarily to sell it to them; but the unlicensed American fishermen cannot buy bait from the bait freezers or from any one else. Therefore, to the extent to which the licensed American fishermen could buy bait, it would be rather harsh, I take it, on our part to intervene and say we ought not to sell it to them.
I am not putting the objection on that ground, but on the ground of public enterprise supplying what might be supplied by private enterprise.

As a rule, I think the bait freezers will supply the bait to the fishermen who are the shareholders in the association itself. Occasionally they may have a surplus to sell to the ships, and in some cases they may sell to licensed American fishermen ; but that will be a very small proportion of the total amount.

speechtext: Since the hon. gentleman has adopted the principle of supplying cold storage for the benefit of the fishermen, I hope he will press on his colleague, the Minister of Agriculture (Hon. Mr. Fisher), the necessity of granting an equally Urge subsidy for the supply of cold storage to the farmers of the country.

I take this opportunity of placing before the members of the House, particularly the members from the west, the importance of this industry which the government are endeavouring to foster in this way. The line fishermen of the maritime provinces number about 20,000, and the annual catch of fish known as line-fish

amounts to about $8,000,000. We have altogether about 45,000 fishermen in the maritime provinces, who, it is estimated lose from thirty to sixty days each in the season for want of a constant supply of fresh bait. The aggregate loss of the fishermen of the maritime provinces on this account amounts altogether to 800,000 to 1,000,000 days of fishing in the year. The fishing industry is our second most important industry. Agriculture, poor as it is with us, is still our first industry. We hear a great deal of our lumber and mining industries in the east; but our fishing industry is far in advance of these in importance, I think more than equal to both combined. So that the House can readily understand that to make provision for overcoming so great a loss as 800,000 or 1,000,000 days of fishing is a matter of vital importance to the maritime provinces. We hear it frequently stated that the fishing population along our coasts is becoming depleted, a believe it is a fact that for years past the industry has been unremunerative. At the same time, our fishermen are large consumers, and very heavy contributors to the revenues. They use large quantities of imported goods and manufactured goods from the west, and their return from their catch of fish has to depend not on any benefit which the government can give them. They have to send their fish to the West Indies, to South America, to Brazil, and to the Mediterranean, in competition with the fish of the whole world. For these reasons the government were urged, some eighteen months ago, to take this step. We recognized that a cold storage system had been established for the benefit of the farmers of the western provinces and the province of Quebec, not only on shore but on sea- a cold storage system virtually extending from their farms to the consumers' tables in the old country ; and we urged that something in the same direction should be done for the fishermen. 1 happen to have been the promoter of this scheme, and I am entirely gratified at the success which it has achieved in so short a time. If hon. members will give it their support, we will not require a great appropriation to establish a pretty effective system all around the coast, from the mouth of the St. Lawrence to the mouth of the St. Croix river. Perhaps from 100 to 110 small freezers will meet the requirements. A considerable number of gentlemen in the maritime provinces, who are well acquainted with the fishing industry, feel sure that this measure will enable our fishermen to realize anywhere from $1,000,000 to $2,000,000 per annum more than they do at present. We expect also to establish a better class of cold storage cars, so that we may send our fish in good condition from the maritime provinces to the west, even as far as Chicago.
To-day we have not in Canada a cold storage' car equal in construction to many used by the Swift and'Armour firms in carrying their freight from Chicago to Portland and Boston. I may say that the Minister of Railways (Hon. Mr. Blair) has employed the expert who made these cars in the western states, to construct two at Moncton on the same plan. What we want is a car that will carry fish, apples and other perishable products without freezing them, and to-day we have not got in Canada a first-class cold storage car.
We may look forward soon to the time when the western part of our country will be populated to a far greater extent than it now is, and furnish a great market for fish, more particularly as the fish of the great lakes, in all probability, will not hold out. We have in our fishermen a large consuming population who are adding to the wealth of the country and contributing very largely to its revenue, and I ask gentlemen from the west, in particular, to take this matter up and give it their best consideration.
I would ask the hon. gentleman whether there is any probability of these establishments being built as commercial enterprises which will be selfsustaining.

I know of three that are to be put up by fish merchants and fishermen, who do not want to be hampered by the restrictions imposed by the government, and I have no doubt quite a number will be put up ns commercial enterprises.
In the larger districts, that is likely to be the case, but in the smaller I suppose government aid will be required for some time to come.
It is proposed to give government aid every year.
We give a small bonus each year for three years, determined on the quantity of bait in the freezers.

speechtext: And after three years the bonus ceases.
Yes.
